III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction, prevention; prohibited
Title restraints; elimination of restraints.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159
Section (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
Description manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the
severity of the youth’s behavior, chronological and
developmental age, size, gender, physical condition, medical
condition, psychiatric
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A had to be restrained on 3/1/24 around 8:30pm. Youth A
was aggressive, kicking, throwing objects, and trying to bite staff.
Youth A was seen by a nurse and reportedly did not have any
bruises. On 3/2/24, Youth A was observed to have a bump on his
forehead. The bruise was 1 inch in diameter.
Investigation Interviews:
I spoke to Foster Care Worker (FCW) on 3/4/24. FCW reported
she picked up Youth A for a home visit and he had a bump and
bruise on his forehead. Youth A reported to her that an unknown
staff gave him the bump from a restraint.
I spoke to Complainant 1 on 3/4/24. No new information was
provided.
I spoke to Administrator 1 on 3/4/24. Allegations were discussed.
Administrator 1 reported Youth A was restrained on 3/1/24 and did
see the nurse.
I spoke to DHHS Worker 1. Allegations were discussed and
scheduling. No other information was discussed.
The following interviews were conducted with DHHS Worker 1 at
the facility on 3/8/24.
Youth A:
Youth A reported he was hurt by a female staff on the right side of
his head. Youth A reported she threw a brush at his head. Youth A
reported he was not hurt in a restraint but afterwards. Youth A no
longer wanted to discuss the situation, so he left the interview.
2

I reviewed the video due to the allegations not matching Youth
A’s interview. On 3/1/24, at 7:05:16 pm, Youth A was in a child
control position, restrained. The restraint position was done in the
manner outlined in the Crisis Prevention Interventions. He was
released from the restraint at 7:09:26 pm. As Youth A stood up, he
stumbled, lost his balance, and hit his forehead on the right side of
the lower glass wall panel. Youth A then went into his bedroom. At
7:17:11pm, Staff 1 went to the doorway of Youth A’s room and
entered Youth A’s room at 7:17:42pm. At 7:18:45pm Staff 1 came
out of his room. No one else was near the bedroom door or
entrance of the door to see the events.
Staff 1:
Staff 1 reported she went into Youth A’s doorway after he was
restrained on 3/1/24. Youth A was upset, and Staff 1 was
attempting to verbally deescalate him. Youth A threw lotion bottles
and his brushes at Staff 1. Staff 1 reported she blocked the brush
with her arm and Youth A began yelling that Staff 1 hit him. Staff 1
reported she wrote an incident report so it would be documented.
Staff 1 reported if she did hit Youth A with a brush it was because
she deflected the brush with her arm when he threw it at her.
Staff 1 reported she did not see him get hit with the brush but
wanted to make sure it was documented because he was yelling
that she had done so. Staff 1 reported no one else was near the
room when she was deescalating Youth A.
Documents:
• I reviewed the Incident Report written by Staff 1 on 3/1/24:
“Resident threw an item at staff, staff attempted to block
item, item ricocheted off staff and hit the resident in the
head”.
• I reviewed the Incident report for the restraint on 3/1/24.
Youth A was aggressive in attacking unidentified staff and
breaking the glass fishtank. Incident report noted a child
control was applied and the nurse did see Youth A after the
restraint. The restraint documentation is in agreement with
Nurse Notes and video observation.
• I reviewed the Nurse Notes for 3/1/24. “Child bumped his
head against the wall, has a quarter sized bump at right
forehead, no broken skin or bruising, attempted to put ice
on forehead but Youth A refused.” **I observed on the
video the Nurse entering Youth A’s room at 7:16:00pm.
She went into his room after he had hit his head on the wall
panel and before Staff 1 entered his room.
3

• I reviewed the McLaren Oakland Emergency Department
Discharge Form. Youth A was seen on 3/2/24. Final
diagnosis: “Minor head injury without LOC. There were no
medications prescribed.” If the condition worsened to see
primary physician.
Analysis Youth A reported he was not hurt in a restraint, but by a female
staff throwing a brush at him. Based on interviews, documents
gathered, and video observation there is not enough evidence to
support Staff 1 purposely hitting Youth A with a brush causing a
bruise. Documentation and video observation support Youth A
hurting himself when he hit his head against the wall panel.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
